sn11.10:1.2: This opening is reminiscent of Ud 1.10, which specifies the location as Suppāraka
sn11.10:1.5: The sages may have been virtuous, but they were not above a little realpolitik.
sn11.10:1.7: A barbarian (dāsa) who “fancied himself godlike” (Rig Veda 7.18.20), Śambara’s 99 mountain forts were destroyed for their bounty (6.47.23) by Indra on behalf of Divodāsa Atithigva (4.26.3). His mention close to Virocana (SN 11.8) fits the Arthaśāstra, where they are both invoked together (14.3.19). Despite his decisive defeat at the hands of Indra, later legend makes him a formidable foe and master of sorcery (see SN 11.23).
sn11.10:5.5: Tāta (“my dear”) here is an endearment of pity (“oh hon”).
sn11.10:6.2: This inverts the power of his magic to put people to sleep (Arthaśāstra 14.3.19).
